content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Marcus Johnson: Well, I was born in Des Moines, Iowa, and I've lived here most of my life. My parents were both working-class folks who didn't have a lot of money, but they always made sure I had the basics. My dad worked at a local factory, and my mom was a nurse's aide. We lived in a small apartment, but I never felt like I was missing out. I was a pretty quiet kid, always reading books or drawing. I remember being really into comic books and science fiction as a teenager, which probably explains why I ended up going to college for something like computer science. I got my bachelor's degree from a state school, which was tough because I had to work part-time to help pay for it. I'm still figuring out what I want to do with my degree, but I know I want to make sure I'm not stuck in the same cycle my parents were in. I'm not really into politics, but I do care about things like fair wages and education access. I've never been married, and I don't really see myself getting married anytime soon. I'm focused on building a stable life for myself, and maybe one day starting my own business.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Marcus Johnson: Yeah, there was definitely a crossroads. I was about 20, right after I started college, and I had this job at a local tech store. I was working 20 hours a week, going to classes, and trying to keep up with my studies. One day, my manager offered me a promotion to a full-time position with better hours and benefits. It would have been a stable job, good pay, and I wouldn't have had to worry about money as much. But I remember sitting there, thinking about my parents and how they had always worked hard but never really had the chance to move up. I didn't want to end up in the same place they were. So I turned down the promotion. It was tough, because I needed the money, but I knew if I stayed in school, I could build something better for myself. That decision probably made me who I am today — someone who's not afraid to take the harder path if it means having more control over my future.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Marcus Johnson: I think it was a conscious choice, even if it didn't feel like it at the time. I was pretty torn, honestly. I remember talking to my mom about it, and she just said, 'You're not going to be happy if you settle for less.' That stuck with me. I didn't want to be one of those people who looked back and wondered what could have been. So I made the decision to stay in school, even though it meant more stress and less money. Looking back, I don't regret it. It was the right call for me, even if it wasn't the easiest one.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Marcus Johnson: Yeah, I think if I had known about some of the financial aid programs or scholarships available at the time, it might have made things a little easier. I remember my mom worked second shift at the hospital, and she never had time to really help me navigate the college application process or the financial aid stuff. I wish there had been someone at the school or in the community who could have sat down with me and explained my options. I know a lot of people don't have the same resources or support systems, so I think organizations that provide mentorship or financial guidance to students from low-income backgrounds could make a huge difference. I've been thinking about volunteering with something like that once I get more stable in my own life.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Marcus Johnson: Right now, I don't have a partner or any children. I've been focused on my studies and building a stable career, and honestly, I haven't really thought much about relationships. I've had a few friends over the years, but nothing serious. My family is still pretty close, though. My parents are both retired now, and they live in the same neighborhood I grew up in. My mom still works part-time at the hospital, and my dad spends a lot of time gardening and fixing things around the house. I try to visit them as much as I can, even if it's just for dinner on the weekends. They've always been supportive of me, even when I was making tough decisions like turning down that job offer. I know they're proud of me, and I want to make sure I don't take them for granted. Family has always been really important to me, even if I haven't always been the best at staying in touch.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how far I've come and how much my upbringing has shaped who I am today. Talking about my life from the beginning brought back a lot of memories, especially the struggles I faced growing up in a working-class family. It was hard to admit how much I relied on my parents' support, but it also reminded me of their sacrifices. The crossroads moment I described, turning down that job offer, was a defining point in my life. It wasn't an easy decision, but it was the right one for me, and I'm proud of the person I've become because of it. I also realized how much I wish I had more guidance when I was in college — it's something I want to give back to others now. And thinking about my family, I'm grateful for their unwavering support. I know I haven't always been the best at staying connected, but I'm making an effort now. Overall, these questions made me appreciate my journey and the choices I've made along the way.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Marcus Johnson: My sister, Tiffany, lives in Chicago now. She's a few years older than me, and she was always the more outgoing one of us. While I was into books and video games, she was the one who got us into music and going to local events. She worked in marketing for a while but eventually went back to school and became a social worker. She's really passionate about helping people, especially kids from tough backgrounds. We don't talk as often as I'd like, but when we do, it's always good. I admire her for the path she's taken, and I think she's been a big influence on me, even if I didn't realize it at the time. She's the one who encouraged me to apply for that scholarship I ended up getting, which helped me afford college. I wish I had stayed in touch more, but I'm trying to make up for that now.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Marcus Johnson: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been really important to me over the years. One of them is Jamal, who I met in college. We both had similar backgrounds — working-class families, first-generation college students trying to figure out our paths. We bonded over our shared struggles and ended up rooming together for a couple of years. Even though we went different ways after graduation — he ended up in the military, and I stayed in the tech field — we still keep in touch. He's been a good influence on me, especially when it came to making tough decisions. There's also Sarah, who I met through a community center program. She's a teacher now, and she's always been the one to push me to think bigger, to not settle for the easy path. I don't know if I'd have made it through college without people like her in my life. I think it's easy to feel like you're on your own, but I've been really lucky to have people who believed in me when I didn't always believe in myself.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Marcus Johnson: I live in a pretty tight-knit neighborhood in Des Moines — one of those places where everyone knows each other, even if they don't always say hello. It's a mix of older homes and newer apartments, mostly family-oriented. There's a community center nearby that hosts a lot of events, from job fairs to youth programs, and I've been volunteering there a bit when I can. It's a good reminder of where I came from and how much I want to give back. The area isn't perfect — there are some issues with gentrification and rising rents — but there's also a strong sense of community. I like that I can walk to a lot of places, and there are a few good coffee shops and bookstores that I frequent. It's not the most exciting place in the world, but it's home, and I feel like I'm part of something bigger here.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Marcus Johnson: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. It's not like the neighborhoods I've heard about in bigger cities, where you have to be careful all the time. Here, people look out for each other. I've never had any real issues, and I think that's because there's a sense of mutual respect. That said, I do notice some changes — especially with the younger generation coming in, some of them not knowing the history of the place or the struggles that people like my parents went through. I worry that as things get more expensive and the character of the neighborhood shifts, some of that community spirit might fade. But for now, I feel safe, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Marcus Johnson: Living here has had its ups and downs, for sure. On the upside, I love the sense of community — the way people know each other, the way neighbors look out for one another. I've been lucky to have friends and mentors who've helped me through tough times, and I think that's something that's really unique to this place. But there are definitely downs too. The cost of living has gone up a lot in the past few years, and I've had to make some tough choices about where to live and how to budget. I used to rent a small apartment not too far from campus, but when the rent got too high, I had to move in with my parents for a while. It wasn't ideal — I was used to being more independent — but it reminded me of where I came from and how much I've grown. I think the biggest challenge is balancing the comfort of home with the need to push myself forward. I don't want to stay stuck in the same place my parents were, but I also know I can't do it all on my own. It's a constant juggle, but I'm learning to navigate it — one step at a time.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety made me reflect on how much my roots still shape my daily life. Talking about my parents and sister reminded me of how important family has always been, even when I wasn't always the best at staying connected. It also made me realize how much I've grown since those days of struggling through college and making tough decisions. Now, living in the same neighborhood I grew up in, I see both the progress and the challenges — the sense of community is still strong, but there are changes happening that I can't ignore. I feel grateful for the people around me, the support I've received, and the opportunities I've been given. At the same time, I know there's still work to be done, both for myself and for the community I care so much about.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Marcus Johnson: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it varies depending on what I'm working on. I work full-time at a tech company, so most days start around 8 or 8:30 in the morning. I usually have a routine — coffee first, then a quick walk to clear my head before diving into work. My job is in software development, which I actually enjoy a lot. It's challenging, but I feel like I'm using the skills I learned in college. After work, I try to make time for some personal projects, like building a website or learning a new programming language. I also volunteer a couple of nights a week at the community center, which is something I really value. On the weekends, I like to catch up with family or friends — my parents usually have dinner on Fridays, and I try to be there if I can. I also go to the library a lot, just to read or work on something without distractions. It's not always perfect — there are days when I'm too tired or stressed to do much — but I like that I have a balance between work, learning, and giving back. It keeps me grounded, and I think that's important, especially coming from where I did.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Marcus Johnson: I work full-time as a software developer at a mid-sized tech company here in Des Moines. My job hours are pretty standard — I start around 8:30 a.m. and usually wrap up around 5 p.m., though I often stay a little later when I'm deep into a project. It's a good fit for me because I enjoy problem-solving and building things, which I think comes from my love of tinkering with computers and video games back when I was younger. The company is pretty supportive, and they offer some professional development opportunities, which I take advantage of whenever I can. I've been in the same role for about two years now, and while it's not the most glamorous job, it pays well and gives me the stability I need to keep working on my personal goals — like starting my own business someday or maybe even going back to school for a master's degree. It's not always easy balancing work with everything else, but I've learned to manage my time better over the years, and I think that's something I owe to the struggles I had growing up.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Marcus Johnson: Outside of work and volunteering, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I try to exercise at least a few times a week — usually running or lifting weights at the community center. It's something I started doing after college, when I realized how much stress I was carrying around. I also make it a point to read every night, even if it's just for 20 or 30 minutes. It's a habit I picked up from my parents, who both loved books, and it's something I really value. I also try to keep in touch with my sister more regularly now, even if it's just a quick call or text. I know I didn't do that enough when we were both younger, and I want to make sure I don't let that happen again. Life is too short to take family for granted, and I'm trying to be more present for the people I care about.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Marcus Johnson: One of the bigger changes to my routine has been starting to explore side projects more seriously. I've been experimenting with developing small apps and even dabbled in freelancing on the weekends. It's a way for me to test out ideas for my own business without committing fully yet. I also started taking evening classes at the community college to brush up on some newer programming languages — something I never really had the chance to do when I was in college. It's been challenging, balancing all of this with my full-time job and volunteering, but I feel like I'm finally in a place where I can start thinking about the future beyond just paying bills. It's weird, but I feel like I'm finally starting to see the path I wanted to take back when I was 20 — the one where I didn't settle for less.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Marcus Johnson: I don't have children yet, but I've been thinking a lot about what that would be like if I ever do. I imagine a typical weekday during the school year would involve getting up early, making sure they have breakfast, and getting them ready for school. I'd probably try to pack their lunch the night before to save time in the morning. After school, I'd want to make sure they have time to do their homework, but also have some fun — maybe sports or art classes, something that helps them explore their interests. I know from my own experience growing up that having structure is important, but so is having time to be creative and just be kids. I'd also want to make sure they're involved in the community, maybe through the same programs I volunteered with, so they can see the value in giving back. It's a lot to think about, but I guess that's part of the journey — figuring out how to be a good parent while still staying true to who I am.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me really think about how much my past has shaped my present. Talking about my family reminded me of how important they've always been, even when I wasn't always the best at staying connected. It also made me realize how far I've come since those days of struggling through college and making tough decisions. Now, living in the same neighborhood I grew up in, I see both the progress and the challenges — the sense of community is still strong, but there are changes happening that I can't ignore. I feel grateful for the people around me, the support I've received, and the opportunities I've been given. At the same time, I know there's still work to be done, both for myself and for the community I care so much about. My daily routine has evolved over time, and I'm finally in a place where I can start thinking about the future beyond just paying bills. It's strange, but I feel like I'm finally starting to see the path I wanted to take back when I was 20 — the one where I didn't settle for less.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Marcus Johnson: As for my health, I'd say I'm pretty average — no major issues, but I've had my share of stress-related stuff, especially during college. I used to have a lot of anxiety, which I think came from the pressure of trying to make it on my own while still supporting myself. I started seeing a counselor a few years back, and that really helped me get a handle on it. I also make sure to take care of myself physically — like I mentioned before, I try to exercise a few times a week and eat reasonably well. I know I could be better about it, but I'm learning. I also try to get enough sleep, though that's harder than it sounds when you're juggling work, volunteering, and personal projects. Overall, I feel like I'm in a good place now, but I know there's always room for improvement. Health is something I've only really started paying attention to in the past few years, and I'm glad I did.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Marcus Johnson: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is having a routine — like the exercise, the reading, and the small moments of mindfulness I try to fit in throughout the day. It's those little habits that keep me grounded. But what makes it hard is the constant juggling act. When I'm working long hours, volunteering, and trying to keep up with personal projects, it's easy to skip a workout or grab fast food instead of cooking something healthy. I also struggle with sleep because my mind is always racing with ideas or worries. I know I need to be better about prioritizing rest, but it's one of those things I keep putting off until tomorrow. I guess the truth is, staying healthy isn't just about making the right choices — it's also about making time for yourself, even when life feels like it's moving a thousand miles a minute.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Marcus Johnson: Actually, nothing too major has happened in the past two years related to my health. I've been pretty consistent with my routine, but there was a time last year when I was working on a big project at work and volunteering a lot more than usual. I started feeling run down, and I think I pushed myself too hard. I ended up with a minor case of burnout — not anything serious, but it was a wake-up call. I had to take a few days off, which was tough because I didn't want to fall behind. It made me realize how important it is to listen to my body and not ignore the signs. Since then, I've been more intentional about pacing myself and making sure I'm not overextending. I also started incorporating some mindfulness practices, like meditation, which has helped me manage stress better. I don't want to go through that again, so I'm trying to be more balanced — not just in my work, but in everything I do.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Marcus Johnson: Honestly, I haven't had any health issues that have really impacted my work or ability to care for others, which I'm grateful for. But I can see how it could happen — especially if someone is juggling a lot of responsibilities like I am. I know people in my neighborhood who have had to take time off work because of health problems, and it's not always easy to get the support they need. I think that's one of the reasons I want to get more involved in community programs — to help make sure people have access to resources that can prevent small issues from becoming bigger ones. It's one thing to take care of yourself, but it's another to make sure others have the same chance. I don't want to be in a position where I can't work or take care of my family because I didn't have the right support when I needed it.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Marcus Johnson: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things — mostly a sense of progress, but also some lingering uncertainty. I've been really proud of myself for sticking to my goals, like finishing that online course in data analysis and starting to take my side projects more seriously. It's been rewarding to see the skills I've been building come together, and I feel like I'm finally in a place where I can start thinking about the future in a more concrete way. That said, there have been moments where I've felt overwhelmed, especially when I'm juggling work, volunteering, and trying to keep up with my personal goals. I've had to learn how to say no to some things and prioritize what really matters. I've also been reflecting a lot on where I came from — how far I've come, but also how much I still have to work on. I think the biggest thing I've been feeling is gratitude. Gratitude for the people who have supported me, for the opportunities I've had, and for the chance to build a better life for myself. It's not always easy, but I'm trying to stay focused on the positive and keep moving forward.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me think a lot about how my daily life has evolved and how I'm finally starting to see the future I wanted for myself. It was interesting to reflect on the changes in my routine, like diving into side projects and taking evening classes — those are things I never really had the chance to do when I was younger, and it feels good to be making progress. At the same time, talking about my health reminded me of how much I've grown in taking care of myself, even if there's still room for improvement. I used to be so focused on just surviving, but now I'm trying to thrive. It's strange how much time has passed since I was 20, making that tough decision to turn down the job offer. Now, I'm finally in a place where I can look back and see how that choice shaped the person I've become — someone who's not afraid to take the harder path, even when it's not easy.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Marcus Johnson: I think I've dealt with anxiety in the past, especially during college when everything felt so uncertain. There were times when I would lie awake at night, worrying about money, my future, and whether I was making the right choices. I didn't want to let my parents down, and I was scared of ending up in the same situation they were in. It wasn't clinical depression, but it felt like a heavy weight on my chest most of the time. I started seeing a counselor a few years back, and that really helped me understand what I was going through. I learned how to recognize the signs and take steps to manage it — like talking to someone, journaling, or just taking a walk when things got too much. I still have days when I feel overwhelmed, especially when I'm juggling a lot of responsibilities, but I've gotten better at handling it. I don't want to minimize what others go through, but I think having that support system — whether it's friends, family, or professionals — makes all the difference. I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm working on it, and that's the most important thing.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Marcus Johnson: For my family, the past year has been a mix of pride and quiet worry. My parents are really proud of me for the progress I've made — getting my degree, landing a stable job, and even starting to think about my own business. They've always believed in me, even when I wasn't sure I believed in myself. But there's also this unspoken worry, especially with my mom, who still works part-time and sees how much I'm trying to do on my own. She worries about me pushing too hard, not taking enough time to rest. I can see it in her eyes when we talk, and I know she's thinking about how she and my dad had to work so hard just to get by. It's not easy for them to watch their kid struggle with the same pressures, even if I'm in a better position now. I try to reassure them that I'm okay, but I also know I need to be more open about how I'm feeling — about the stress, the uncertainty, the moments when I feel like I'm not doing enough. I want them to know that I'm not just trying to build a better life for myself, but also for them. I want them to see that their sacrifices weren't in vain, and that I'm finally on a path where I can give them the kind of life they never had.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Marcus Johnson: I wouldn't say religion or spirituality plays a big role in my life the way it did when I was younger. When I was 16, I was raised in a Protestant household, and church was a regular part of our lives. My parents believed in it, and I went along with it, but I never really connected with it on a personal level. Over time, as I got older and started thinking more about who I was and what I believed in, I drifted away from organized religion. I don't feel like I need a higher power to guide me — I prefer to look inward, to my values, my family, and the people who have supported me along the way. That said, I do think about the importance of community and helping others, which I guess is a kind of spiritual belief in its own way. I don't go to church anymore, but I still find meaning in the connections I have with others and the work I do to give back. It's not the same as what I had growing up, but I think it's a different kind of faith — one that's rooted in action and relationships rather than doctrine.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Marcus Johnson: I use social media more for staying in touch with friends and family than for keeping up with the wider world. I have a Facebook account where I post mostly photos of my parents, my sister, and the occasional project I'm working on. I don't use Instagram much — I find it a bit too focused on appearances, and honestly, I don't have the time or energy to curate a perfect online image. I do follow some local news pages and community groups, though, just to stay informed about what's going on in Des Moines. I also use LinkedIn for professional stuff — it's helpful for networking and keeping up with industry trends in tech. But I'm not really into the whole 'influencer' culture or the constant comparison that comes with platforms like TikTok or Twitter. I think I've always been more of a private person, and I value real connections over online validation. That said, I do appreciate the convenience of being able to reach out to someone instantly, whether it's my sister in Chicago or a friend from college. It's not perfect, but it's a tool I use — just not one I let define me.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Marcus Johnson: Honestly, I haven't really relied on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times. I know people do it, and I can see how it might help — especially for someone who doesn't have a strong support system. But for me, it's always been about the people I know in real life. When I was going through college and struggling with that job offer decision, it was my mom who gave me the push I needed, not someone I saw online. I think I've always been more of a face-to-face kind of person. That said, I do appreciate the way social media can connect people, especially in communities like mine where resources aren't always easy to find. I've seen local groups post about scholarships, job opportunities, or even mental health resources, and that's definitely been helpful. It's just not the first place I turn to when things get tough. I prefer talking to someone I know, someone who's been through something similar — even if it's just a friend from college or a neighbor who understands what it's like to grow up in this neighborhood.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health and mental well-being have shaped my journey over the past few years. It was eye-opening to talk about the burnout I experienced last year and how it forced me to slow down and prioritize self-care. I used to think that pushing through was the only way to succeed, but now I see that taking care of myself is just as important as working hard. It also made me think about how lucky I am to have a support system — my family, friends, and even the community programs I've been involved with — because I know not everyone has that. I still have days where I feel overwhelmed, but I'm learning to recognize the signs and take action before things get too heavy. It's not always easy, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made and the understanding I've gained about what it really means to take care of myself, both physically and mentally.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Marcus Johnson: In the past year, my stress levels have definitely fluctuated — there were times when I felt like I was on top of everything, and other times when I was barely keeping my head above water. The biggest shift for me has been learning how to recognize when I'm getting overwhelmed and taking steps to address it before it spirals. I used to push through everything, thinking that if I just worked harder, I could handle it all. But I've started to realize that burnout isn't something you can just power through. Now, when I feel the weight of too many responsibilities, I take a step back. I might go for a run, call my sister, or even just sit in silence for a while and let my thoughts settle. I've also started journaling more, which helps me process my emotions and see patterns in how I react to stress. It's not perfect — I still have days where I feel like I'm not doing enough — but I'm getting better at managing it. I think the biggest change is that I'm no longer afraid to ask for help, whether it's from a friend, a mentor, or even just taking a break. I've come to understand that taking care of my emotional health isn't a weakness — it's a necessary part of being able to keep moving forward.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Marcus Johnson: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and car payments. I live in a small apartment not too far from downtown, and the rent has gone up a bit over the past year, which has been a challenge. Groceries are another big one — I try to eat healthy, but with my schedule, it's easier to grab something quick from the store, which ends up costing more. My car is older, but it's reliable, and the payments are pretty standard. I also set aside money for utilities, insurance, and a small emergency fund. I've been trying to track my spending more carefully, especially with all the side projects and evening classes I've been taking on. It's not always easy to balance everything, but I've learned that small adjustments — like cooking more at home or using public transportation when I can — help a lot. I know I'm not in a position where I have to worry about money the way my parents did, but I also know I can't afford to be careless with it. It's one of those things I have to stay on top of, especially if I want to save for my own business someday.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Marcus Johnson: To be honest, my monthly spending has been pretty consistent over the past few months, though there have been a few fluctuations. On average, I spend around $1,800 to $2,000 a month. The majority of that goes to rent, which is about $900, and groceries, which usually come in around $400. Car payments are another big chunk — about $250 — and then there's utilities, insurance, and a few other smaller expenses like phone bills and streaming services. I also try to set aside some money for savings, even if it's just a small amount each month. It's not always easy, especially when I'm working late or volunteering, but I've learned that budgeting is something I have to stay on top of if I want to keep moving forward. I know I'm not in a position where I have to worry about money the way my parents did, but I also know I can't afford to be careless with it. It's one of those things I have to stay on top of, especially if I want to save for my own business someday.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Marcus Johnson: We rent our home — it's a small apartment not too far from downtown. I've been living there for about a year now, and while it's not the most luxurious place, it's convenient and within my budget. I actually moved in with my parents for a while after college when the rent in my old place got too high, but I knew I needed to be more independent if I wanted to build something for myself. Renting has its pros and cons — I don't have the burden of a mortgage, but I also don't have the security of owning a home. I've been thinking about buying a place someday, but right now, I'm focused on saving up and making sure I'm in a stable financial position. It's one of those things I want to get right, especially after seeing how hard my parents worked just to have a place to call home.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Marcus Johnson: Over the past year, my bills have definitely had their ups and downs, especially with the seasons and some unexpected expenses. For example, during the winter, my heating bill went up a bit, which I didn't really anticipate. I had to adjust my budget to cover that, which meant cutting back on some of my streaming subscriptions and eating out less. Then there was the holiday season — I ended up spending more than I expected on gifts for my parents and sister, even though I tried to keep it simple. I also had to replace my car's alternator last spring, which was a surprise expense that threw my budget off for a few months. On the flip side, some months were easier — like when I got a small bonus at work or saved up enough to cover a few bills at once. It's been a learning experience, honestly. I've started tracking my expenses more closely and setting aside a little extra each month for unexpected costs. It's not perfect, but it's helping me feel more in control of my finances, which is something I really value after growing up in a household where money was always tight.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me think a lot about how my family's support has been a constant in my life, even as I've grown and changed. It was meaningful to talk about how my parents feel proud of me, but also worried about the pressures I'm under. I realized how much they've sacrificed, and how much I want to make sure I don't repeat the same struggles they faced. It also made me reflect on how I rely on real, face-to-face connections rather than online ones for support — something I'm grateful for, but also something I know not everyone has access to. I've come to see that while social media can be a tool for connection, it's not a substitute for the kind of support I get from my family and friends. It's a reminder that I need to keep nurturing those relationships, even as I focus on my own goals and future.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Marcus Johnson: I do save, though it's more of a habit than a formal plan. I set aside a small portion of my paycheck each month — usually around $100 to $150 — into a savings account. It's not a lot, but it's something. I know from growing up that having a little cushion can make all the difference, especially when unexpected things come up. I also try to save in other ways, like buying secondhand clothes or using coupons when I shop. I remember my mom always saying, 'Save a little every day, and it adds up,' and I think that's stuck with me. I don't have a lot, but I'm trying to be smart about it. I want to make sure that if I ever decide to start my own business or go back to school for a master's degree, I have some financial stability to fall back on. It's not about being rich — it's about having options, and I think that's something I owe to the struggles I've been through.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Marcus Johnson: In the last year, I've been saving more with a specific goal in mind — eventually buying a home. It's something I never thought I'd be able to do growing up, seeing how hard my parents worked just to have a stable place to live. I know it's a long way off, but I'm trying to be intentional about it. Right now, my savings are going toward a down payment fund, and I've also been looking into first-time homebuyer programs to see what options are available. I don't want to rush into anything, but I do want to make sure I'm building a future where I don't have to worry about where I live. It's not just about having a roof over my head — it's about creating a space that feels like mine, a place where I can finally stop worrying about money and start thinking about what I really want for myself and my family.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Marcus Johnson: My occupation is a software developer, and I work at a mid-sized tech company here in Des Moines. My main responsibilities involve designing and maintaining software applications for clients in a variety of industries, from healthcare to education. A typical day involves coding, debugging, collaborating with other developers, and meeting with clients to understand their needs and ensure the software aligns with their goals. One of the most important aspects of my job is problem-solving — figuring out how to make complex systems work efficiently and effectively. I also spend a lot of time staying up-to-date with new technologies and programming languages, which is something I really enjoy. It's rewarding to see the impact of the work I do, even if it's not always visible to the public. I think what makes this job meaningful for me is that it's a way to use the skills I developed in college and apply them to real-world challenges. Plus, it gives me the stability I need to focus on my personal goals, like starting my own business or even going back to school for a master's degree someday.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Marcus Johnson: I usually work around 40 to 45 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the project I'm working on. Some weeks are pretty straightforward — I clock in, do my tasks, and go home around 5 p.m. But other times, especially when we're launching a new feature or dealing with a tight deadline, I end up staying late or even working a few hours on weekends. I've gotten used to it, but I also know the importance of balance. That's why I try to make sure I have time for my personal projects, volunteering, and staying in touch with family. It's not always easy, but I've learned that working hard doesn't mean working nonstop — it means working smart and making sure I take care of myself along the way.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Marcus Johnson: I didn't have more than one job for a long time — I was pretty focused on making sure the one I had was stable enough to support me through school and after. But in the past year or so, I've started taking on some freelance work on the weekends, mostly developing small apps or helping local businesses with their websites. It's not a full-time gig, but it gives me a little extra income and lets me experiment with different projects. I also do some evening classes at the community college, which I consider part of my 'job' in a way — it's about investing in myself and learning new skills. I know it's not the same as having multiple jobs, but I think it's a way of balancing work with growth. I don't want to burn out, but I also don't want to settle for just one path. It's a delicate balance, but I'm learning to manage it.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my stress levels have changed over the past year and how I've started to take my emotional health more seriously. It was interesting to think about how I used to push through everything without really acknowledging how overwhelmed I was. Now, I've learned to recognize the signs and take steps to address them — whether it's going for a run, calling my sister, or just taking a moment to breathe. I also realized how important it is to have a support system — not just for emotional reasons, but for practical ones too, like managing my finances and making sure I'm not overspending. It's not always easy to stay on top of everything, but I'm learning that balance is key. I'm grateful for the progress I've made, even if there's still a long way to go.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Marcus Johnson: In terms of income, my household — which is just me right now — made around $3,200 last month. That's mostly from my full-time job as a software developer, and a little bit from the freelance work I've been doing on the side. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover my expenses and save a little for the future. I know it's more than my parents ever made at my age, and that's something I'm really grateful for. I've been trying to be careful with my money, not just because I want to save for a house someday, but also because I know how tight things can get if you're not prepared. It's strange, really — I used to worry so much about not having enough, but now I'm starting to feel like I have a little more control over my financial future. I just hope I can keep it up and make sure I'm not repeating the same struggles my parents had.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Marcus Johnson: I've been at my current job for about two years now, and honestly, it's been a good fit for me. The company offers a solid benefits package — health insurance, dental, vision, and a decent amount of paid time off. I get about 15 days of vacation a year, plus sick days and holidays. It's not the most generous package I've heard of, but it's enough to cover my needs. One of the things I really appreciate is the flexibility — they allow remote work a few days a week, which is helpful when I need to focus on personal projects or volunteer work. The culture is pretty collaborative, and I feel like my contributions are valued. I know not everyone has the same opportunities, especially in places like Des Moines, where tech jobs aren't as common. I'm grateful for the stability and the chance to grow within the company, even if it's not the most glamorous job. It's just another step toward building the life I want — one where I can support myself and eventually give back to the community that helped me get here.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Marcus Johnson: My relationships at work are pretty good overall — I feel like I have a solid rapport with my manager and a lot of my coworkers. My manager, Karen, is someone I really respect. She's been in the industry for a while, and she's always willing to listen when I have questions or need guidance. She's not one of those bosses who just wants results — she actually cares about her team and wants us to grow. That makes a big difference, especially when you're trying to balance work with everything else in your life. As for my coworkers, most of them are pretty friendly and collaborative. We work on different projects, but there's a sense of camaraderie — we'll grab lunch together or chat about things outside of work. I think it helps that we all come from similar backgrounds — a lot of us are first-generation college graduates or people who had to work their way up. It creates a kind of mutual understanding, even if we don't always agree on everything. I wouldn't say it's perfect — there are definitely times when things get tense or when priorities clash — but for the most part, I feel supported and valued at work, which is something I didn't take for granted growing up.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Marcus Johnson: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's also a fair amount of flexibility, which I really appreciate. I usually start around 8:30 a.m. and finish around 5 p.m., but I can sometimes adjust my hours if I need to work from home or stay late on a project. The company allows remote work a couple of days a week, which is helpful when I need to focus on personal projects or volunteer work. That said, there are times when the schedule can be less predictable — especially when we're launching a new feature or dealing with a tight deadline. I've learned to be flexible with my time, but I also make sure to set boundaries so I don't end up working all the time. It's a balance, and I think that's something I've had to work on since I was younger, when I was used to juggling school, work, and family responsibilities all at once. Now, I'm trying to be more intentional about how I use my time — not just for work, but for the things that matter most to me.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Marcus Johnson: Overall, I feel pretty good about my financial situation, but it's not without its challenges. I know I'm in a better position than my parents were at my age, and that gives me a sense of accomplishment. I'm able to cover my basic needs, save a little for the future, and even take on some side projects without the constant fear of not making it. That said, I'm not naive — I know that one unexpected expense or a downturn in the economy could throw me off track. I've been trying to be more mindful of how I spend my money, not just for my own stability, but also so I can eventually give back to the community that helped me get here. I want to make sure I'm not just surviving, but actually thriving, and that I'm building a life where I can support others the way I was supported. It's a work in progress, but I'm proud of how far I've come.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how my financial situation has evolved over the past year and how I've started to take more control of my future. Talking about my bills and how they fluctuate reminded me of the struggles my parents faced growing up, and it made me more determined to be proactive about my finances. It also made me realize how much I've learned about budgeting and saving — things I never really thought about when I was younger. I used to worry so much about not having enough, but now I feel like I'm finally in a place where I can plan for the future without constantly looking over my shoulder. It's not perfect, and I know there's still a long way to go, but I'm proud of the progress I've made. I'm starting to see that financial stability isn't just about making ends meet — it's about having the freedom to make choices, to take risks, and to build something better for myself and the people I care about.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Marcus Johnson: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My dad worked at a local factory, and my mom was a nurse's aide at the hospital. They both had pretty stable jobs, but they didn't make a lot of money — just enough to cover the basics. I remember my mom working second shift a lot, which meant she was gone when I got home from school, and my dad was always coming home tired from his shift. They never complained, though. They always made sure I had food on the table and a place to sleep, even when things were tight. I think that's why I've always been so determined to build a better life for myself — I don't want to repeat the same struggles they had. It's funny, though — I used to think they were just working hard to support me, but now I realize they were also working hard to support themselves. They never asked for much, but they gave me everything they could. I'm still trying to figure out how to pay them back, in my own way.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Marcus Johnson: My dad worked at a local factory assembling parts for agricultural machinery. It was a physically demanding job — long hours, repetitive work, and not much in the way of benefits. He always said it paid the bills, and that was enough. My mom worked as a nurse's aide at the hospital, which meant she was on her feet all day, helping patients with their daily needs, assisting doctors, and making sure people were comfortable. She never had time for much else, but she always made sure I had what I needed. I remember her coming home exhausted but still trying to help me with my homework or fix my bike when it broke. Both of them had jobs that were stable but not glamorous — the kind of work that keeps the world running, even if it doesn't always get the recognition it deserves. I think that's why I've always felt a responsibility to do something more with my life, to make sure I'm not just surviving but actually contributing in a way that matters.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Marcus Johnson: My dad worked for a company called Midwestern AgTech, which was a medium-sized manufacturer of equipment used in farming and agriculture. It was one of those places that had been around for decades, and a lot of the workers had been there for years — some of them even longer than my dad. He was one of the assembly line workers, putting together parts for tractors and harvesters. It wasn't the kind of job that required a lot of education, but it did require a lot of physical strength and attention to detail. My mom worked at Des Moines General Hospital, which was a pretty busy place back then. She was part of the support staff, helping nurses with patients, making sure they had clean clothes, and assisting with basic care. She didn't get a lot of time off, and she never really had the chance to move up in the hospital's hierarchy. Both of them did their jobs with a lot of pride, even if they didn't get much in the way of recognition or rewards. I remember my dad talking about how he didn't mind the work because it gave him a sense of purpose — he was helping build machines that farmers used to grow food. My mom, on the other hand, always said she was doing something that mattered, even if it was just helping someone feel a little better for a day. I think that's why I've always believed in the value of hard work — not just for the money, but for the sense of contribution it brings.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Marcus Johnson: A few years from now, I hope I'm in a place where I can finally stop worrying about money and start focusing on what really matters — not just for myself, but for the people I care about. I see myself still living in Des Moines, maybe even in a home of my own, but not just for the stability — I want it to be a place where I can host family dinners, have friends over, and maybe even start a small community tech program to help kids from backgrounds like mine. I want to be someone who's not just surviving, but actually thriving, and who can give back in a way that makes a real difference. I also hope I'm further along with my own business idea — something that combines my love for technology with my passion for helping others. I don't know exactly what that will look like, but I know I want to build something that lasts, something that gives me purpose beyond just a paycheck. And most of all, I hope I'm still growing — not just professionally, but as a person. I want to be someone who's not afraid to take risks, who's still curious about the world, and who remembers where they came from. That's the kind of future I want to work toward — one where I can look back and say, 'I made the right choices,' and feel proud of the life I've built.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Marcus Johnson: What I value the most in my life is connection — the real, meaningful kind. It's not just about family or friends, though they're definitely a big part of it. I value the relationships that make me feel seen, supported, and challenged to be better. I think growing up in a working-class family taught me that life isn't just about individual success, but about how we lift each other up. I value the moments when I can sit with my parents, listen to their stories, and share mine. I value the friendships that have helped me through tough times, like Jamal and Sarah, who've been there even when I wasn't sure I had the strength to keep going. I also value the sense of purpose that comes from giving back — whether it's volunteering at the community center or thinking about how I can help kids from similar backgrounds one day. I think that's what keeps me grounded: knowing that I'm not just building a life for myself, but also for the people who believed in me when I didn't believe in myself.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my work and financial situation have shaped my sense of stability and purpose. Talking about my income, my job, and the benefits I receive reminded me of how far I've come from the days of struggling through college and worrying about making ends meet. It also made me think about how important it is to have a job that not only pays the bills but also offers flexibility, support, and opportunities for growth. I'm grateful for the stability I have now, but I also know that it's not just about the paycheck — it's about the relationships I've built at work, the sense of accomplishment I feel when I'm doing meaningful work, and the freedom to pursue my own goals. It's strange how much my past has influenced my present, but I'm proud of the person I've become and the life I'm building for myself.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection, not just for the people who asked the questions, but for me as well. It's amazing how much I've learned about myself when I've had to talk through my past, my struggles, my choices, and my hopes for the future. I never really thought about how much my upbringing shaped who I am today — how my parents' sacrifices, my sister's influence, and the support of friends like Jamal and Sarah all played a role in getting me to where I am now. I've always known I wanted to build a better life, but now I see how much that desire came from watching my parents work so hard without much reward. I also see how much I've grown — from the quiet kid who loved books and comic books to the person who turned down a stable job to pursue a degree, and now to someone who's not just surviving but trying to thrive. I've learned that it's okay to struggle, to feel overwhelmed, and to ask for help. What I didn't realize was how much my story is connected to the people around me — my family, my community, and the people who believed in me when I didn't believe in myself. This interview has reminded me of how far I've come, but also how much more there is to do. I want to keep growing, keep giving back, and keep building a future that's not just for me, but for the people who helped me get here.
